authors.name: Gábor Klaniczay
authors.bio: Gábor Klaniczay (1950–) is a Hungarian historian, a specialist in the history of religions and cultures of Renaissance and Baroque Europe.

authors.name: Bryan A. Garner
authors.bio: Bryan Andrew Garner (1958–) is an American lawyer, lexicographer, and legal writing expert. He is the author of several influential books on legal writing and style.

authors.name: Christopher Manson
authors.bio: Christopher Manson (1950?) is an American author and illustrator, best known for his puzzle book MAZE published in 1985.

authors.name: Amy Hennig
authors.bio: Amy Hennig (1964–) is an American video game director and scriptwriter, known for her work on the Uncharted series and Legacy of Kain series.

authors.name: Alan Moore
authors.bio: Alan Moore (1953–) is an English author widely recognised as one of the best comic book writers in the English language.

authors.name: H. P. Lovecraft
authors.bio: Howard Phillips Lovecraft (1890–1937) was an American writer of weird, horror, fantasy, and science fiction. He is best known for his creation of the Cthulhu Mythos, but his legacy is also apparent in terms like "Lovecraftian horror" and an enduring fandom.

authors.name: David Foster Wallace
authors.bio: David Foster Wallace (1962–2008) was an American writer and professor of English and creative writing. He is best known for his novel "Infinite Jest," which explores themes of addiction, entertainment, and the search for meaning in contemporary life.

authors.name: J. K. Rowling
authors.bio: Joanne Rowling (1965–) is a British author, best known for writing the Harry Potter fantasy series, which has won multiple awards and sold more than 500 million copies worldwide.

authors.name: Frank Herbert
authors.bio: Franklin Patrick Herbert Jr. (1920–1986) was an American science-fiction author best known for his 1965 novel Dune and its five sequels.

authors.name: William Shakespeare
authors.bio: William Shakespeare (1564–1616) was an English playwright, poet, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world's pre-eminent dramatist.

authors.name: F. Scott Fitzgerald
authors.bio: Francis Scott Key Fitzgerald (1896–1940) was an American novelist, essayist, screenwriter, and short-story writer, widely regarded as one of the greatest American writers of the 20th century.

authors.name: Charles Darwin
authors.bio: Charles Robert Darwin (1809–1882) was an English naturalist, geologist and biologist, best known for his contributions to the science of evolution.

authors.name: J. R. R. Tolkien
authors.bio: John Ronald Reuel Tolkien (1892–1973) was an English writer, poet, philologist, and academic, best known for his high-fantasy works The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.

authors.name: John Milton
authors.bio: John Milton (1608–1674) was an English poet and intellectual, best known for his epic poem "Paradise Lost," which explores themes of theology, free will, and the human condition.

authors.name: Marcus Aurelius
authors.bio: Marcus Aurelius Antoninus (121–180) was Roman emperor from 161 to 180 and a Stoic philosopher.

authors.name: Mihaly Csikszentmihaly
authors.bio: Csíkszentmihályi Mihály Róbert (1934–2021) was a Hungarian-American psychologist. He recognized and named the psychological concept of "flow", a highly focused mental state conducive to productivity.

authors.name: Michael Wood
authors.bio: Michael Wood (1948–) is a British historian, author and television presenter. He is best known for his historical and archaeological documentaries for the BBC and PBS.

authors.name: Blake Snyder
authors.bio: Blake Snyder (1957–2009) was an American screenwriter, consultant, author and educator based in Los Angeles.

authors.name: Nicolo Machiavelli
authors.bio: Niccolò di Bernardo dei Machiavelli (1469–1527) was a Florentine diplomat, author, philosopher, and historian who lived during the Italian Renaissance. He is regarded as the father of modern political philosophy and political science.

authors.name: Hans H. Ørberg
authors.bio: Hans H. Ørberg (1920–2010) was a Danish linguist and educator, best known for his innovative approach to teaching Latin through the natural method, as presented in his book "Lingua Latina per se Illustrata."

authors.name: Jean Delumeau
authors.bio: Jean Léon Marie Delumeau (1923–2020) was a French historian, specializing in the history of the Catholic Church and Western mentalities.

authors.name: Aristotle
authors.bio: Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and polymath. His writings cover a broad range of subjects. He set the groundwork for the development of modern science.

authors.name: Robert Browning
authors.bio: Robert Browning (1812–1889) was an English poet and playwright. He was noted for irony, characterization, dark humour, social commentary, historical settings and challenging vocabulary and syntax.

authors.name: Alfred, Lord Tennyson
authors.bio: Alfred, Lord Tennyson (1809–1892) was an English poet. He was Poet Laureate of the United Kingdom during much of Queen Victoria's reign.

authors.name: George Gordon Byron
authors.bio: George Gordon Byron (1788–1824) was a British poet, a leading figure in the Romantic movement. He is best known for his flamboyant style and exploration of themes like love, nature, and individualism.

authors.name: William Wordsworth
authors.bio: William Wordsworth (1770–1850) was an English poet who helped to launch the Romantic Age in English literature. He is best known for his nature poetry and his emphasis on emotion and individual experience.

authors.name: William Blake
authors.bio: William Blake (1757–1827) was an English poet, painter, and printmaker. Largely unrecognized during his lifetime, Blake is now considered a seminal figure in the history of the poetry and visual arts of the Romantic Age.

authors.name: Laurence Sterne
authors.bio: Laurence Sterne (1713–1768) was an Irish novelist and an Anglican clergyman. He is best known for his novel "Tristram Shandy", which is considered one of the great comic masterpieces of English literature.

authors.name: Thomas Gray
authors.bio: Thomas Gray (1716–1771) was an English poet, letter-writer, and classical scholar. Gray was a self-critical writer who published only 13 poems in his lifetime, despite being very popular. He was even offered the position of Poet Laureate in 1757 though he declined.

authors.name: Daniel Defoe
authors.bio: Daniel Defoe (1660–1731) was an English writer, merchant and spy. He has been seen as one of the earliest proponents of the English novel, and helped to popularise the form in Britain.

authors.name: Alexander Pope
authors.bio: Alexander Pope (1688–1744) was an English poet, translator, and satirist of the Enlightenment era. An exponent of Augustan literature, Pope is best known for his satirical poetry and translations of Homer.

authors.name: William Wycherley
authors.bio: William Wycherley (1641–1716) was an English dramatist of the Restoration period, best known for his satirical comedies that critique the manners and morals of his time.

authors.name: John Dryden
authors.bio: John Dryden (1631–1700) was an English poet, literary critic, translator, and playwright who in 1668 was appointed England's first Poet Laureate.
